discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BCD
The point of auto-scale is provide additional CPU capability. And Why the system needs more CPU ? to allow for more concurrent processes to run.
So A is false because the number of CPUs changed and are displayed.
and E is false because the point of the incresed CPU is to allow more processes to run, thus more concurrency, which is not the same as higher Level of parallelism. concurrency is more independent processes. Parallelism is on slaves running the same query. 
The optimizer still keeps the same parameter setting for parallel

Answer = BCE

https://docs.oracle.com/en/cloud/paas/autonomous-database/adbsa/autonomous-auto-scale.html#GUID-27FAB1C1-B09F-4A7A-9FB9-5CB8110F7141

Enabling auto scaling does not change the concurrency and parallelism settings for the predefined services.

https://docs.oracle.com/en/cloud/paas/autonomous-database/adbsa/monitor-performance-intro.html#GUID-54CCC1C6-C32E-47F4-8EB6-64CD6EDB5938

Read the CPU section.

With auto scaling enabled the database can use up to three times more CPU and IO resources than specified by the number of OCPUs currently shown in the Scale Up/Down
BCE do not change

Amount of storage NO CHANGES.
The correct answer is B,C,E

BCE are correct, because the amount of storage (B) does not depend on auto-scaling.
AD are incorrect because the the number of OCPU displayed (A) may change if this is the number displayed in the Monitoring page.
A and D can change .. CPUs displays and I/O can change if the database determine that it requires to increase.
I think the correct answer is B,C,E. Enabling auto-scaling doesn't change the storage

Just for reference, the specified answers (ACE) are correct, more information at:

https://docs.oracle.com/en/cloud/paas/autonomous-database/adbsa/autonomous-auto-scale.html#GUID-27FAB1C1-B09F-4A7A-9FB9-5CB8110F7141

Quote:
Enabling auto scaling does not change the concurrency and parallelism settings for the predefined services

choices.A: Number of OCPUs displayed in the console.

questions.question_text: When enabling auto-scaling, which three options do not change? (Choose three.)
Which data file format is NOT supported when using the package DBMS_CLOUD on Shared Exadata Infrastructure? (Choose the best answer.)

discussion.content: Answer A seems to be correct. MDF type is not in the list of the supported formats.
A is correct. .mdf format is for MS SQL server database file

The PL/SQL package DBMS_CLOUD provides support for loading data from:
text, ORC, Parquet, and Avro files in the Cloud to your tables
Answer: A
https://docs.oracle.com/en/cloud/paas/atp-cloud/atpgs/load-data-dbms-cloud.html#GUID-07900054-CB65-490A-AF3C-39EF45505802

choices.D: For databases on dedicated Exadata infrastructure, the maximum number of cores available to a database depends on the total number of cores available in the Exadata infrastructure instance.
choices.A: The base number of OCPU cores allocated to a database is not guaranteed.
choices.B: Auto scaling is enabled by default and can be enabled or disabled at any time.
choices.C: For databases on dedicated Exadata infrastructure, the maximum number of cores is limited by the number of free cores that aren't being used by other auto scaling databases to meet high-load demands.

questions.question_text:
Autonomous Database's auto scaling feature allows your database to use up to three times the current base number of CPU cores at any time. As demand increases, auto scaling automatically increases the number of cores in use. Likewise, as demand drops, auto scaling automatically decreases the number of cores in use.
Which statement is FALSE regarding the auto scaling feature? (Choose the best answer.)

discussion.content:
A. is the right answer. 
Again look which statement is FALSE is the question not which is right. Base # of OCPUS are granteed.

questions.question_text: How can an Autonomous Database resource be provisioned without logging into the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure console? (Choose the best answer.)

choices.D: Using Database Configuration Assistant (DBCA) on the database server.
choices.B: Using the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Command Line interface tool or REST API calls.
choices.C: Connecting to the Cloud Infrastructure Command console via SSH wallet.

questions.question_text: In the Autonomous Database (ADB) Dedicated service, what does the fleet administrator use to control OCPU utilization? (Choose the best answer.)
